channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Comedy and chemistry come naturally to Nobody Wants This's Justine Lupe
item.description: Justine Lupe on season two of Nobody Wants This and why Morgan's story hits closer to home this time
item.content:encoded: Justine Lupe on season two of Nobody Wants This and why Morgan's story hits closer to home this time
item.dc:creator: Sarah Handel

item.title: A decade after a village clash in India, a new book asks how neighbors become enemies
item.description: Renowned comic journalist Joe Sacco on how a 2013 conflict between Hindus and Muslims in India became a window into the stories people tell about violence, identity, and belonging
item.content:encoded: Renowned comic journalist Joe Sacco on how a 2013 conflict between Hindus and Muslims in India became a window into the stories people tell about violence, identity, and belonging
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: As the World Cup heads to North America, more teams are competing than ever before
item.description: The expanded World Cup brings new nations, visa hurdles, and political tension to the global stage, says The Athletic's Paul Tenorio
item.content:encoded: The expanded World Cup brings new nations, visa hurdles, and political tension to the global stage, says The Athletic's Paul Tenorio
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen

item.title: NPR's Jane Arraf reflects on decades of covering the Middle East
item.description: Speaking from Amman, Jordan's capital, Arraf describes how the ceasefire is holding, the toll of years of war on ordinary people, and what feels different in the region today.
item.content:encoded: Speaking from Amman, Jordan's capital, Arraf describes how the ceasefire is holding, the toll of years of war on ordinary people, and what feels different in the region today.
item.dc:creator: Linah Mohammad

item.title: Is silver the new gold? Prices surge as demand outpaces supply
item.description: Veteran metals trader Robert Gottlieb explains the forces behind silver's record highs and what's next for investors
item.content:encoded: Veteran metals trader Robert Gottlieb explains the forces behind silver's record highs and what's next for investors
item.dc:creator: Gabriel J. SÃ¡nchez

item.title: For four years she hid her Parkinson's diagnosis. Then she let a reporter follow her journey.
item.description: Dr. Sue Goldie and New York Times reporter John Branch recount how a private, years-long conversation about her Parkinson's became a public story.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Sue Goldie and New York Times reporter John Branch recount how a private, years-long conversation about her Parkinson's became a public story.
item.dc:creator: Ava Berger

item.title: Across the U.S., 'No Kings' rallies draw crowds protesting President Trump's leadership
item.description: Demonstrations are winding down this evening after a day of coordinated "No Kings" marches and rallies held in cities across the country.
item.content:encoded: Demonstrations are winding down this evening after a day of coordinated "No Kings" marches and rallies held in cities across the country.
item.dc:creator: Martin Kaste

item.title: Sudan Archives shared how synthesizers and tech shaped her new album
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Brittney Denise Sparks of Sudan Archives about her new album The BPM. She talks about how discovering the electric violin in her teens changed things for her.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Brittney Denise Sparks of Sudan Archives about her new album The BPM. She talks about how discovering the electric violin in her teens changed things for her.
item.dc:creator: Ailsa Chang

item.title: Jeff Hiller's Emmy win has been surprisingly meaningful for him, he says
item.description: Jeff Hiller won an Emmy this year for his role in HBO's "Somebody Somewhere." The recognition came after decades of bit roles in TV. And he says the win has been unexpectedly meaningful for him.
item.content:encoded: Jeff Hiller won an Emmy this year for his role in HBO's "Somebody Somewhere." The recognition came after decades of bit roles in TV. And he says the win has been unexpectedly meaningful for him.

item.title: Intense mental exercise may be able to offset the effects of aging, research finds
item.description: A new study shows that cognitive training can increase the levels of a key chemical messenger in the brain responsible for decision-making.
item.content:encoded: A new study shows that cognitive training can increase the levels of a key chemical messenger in the brain responsible for decision-making.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton
